title: 114_hr5480
content: The "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, equal to 50% of the payments, with an annual limit of $500. There is a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a modified adjusted gross income limitation. The credit is subject to a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a modified adjusted gross income limitation. The credit is subject to a lifetime limitation of 10 years and a modified adjusted gross income limitation. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' means adjusted gross income increased by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. Excess home mortgage principal payments refer to the amount of principal paid by the taxpayer exceeding what would have been paid during the taxable year. The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to acquisition indebtedness on a primary residence, defined in section 163(h)(3)(B). The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to acquisition indebtedness on a primary residence that meets specific criteria, including being a traditional mortgage with a term of 15 to 30 years. The term 'qualified home mortgage indebtedness' refers to traditional mortgages on primary residences with terms of 15 to 30 years, with equal payments made at regular intervals. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for the credit. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for the credit under this section unless they file a joint return with their spouse. If the credit is allowed for a joint return, it is treated as allowed to both spouses for that taxable year. For joint returns, both spouses are treated as allowed the credit under subsection (a) for 10 or more preceding taxable years. Reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments is also amended in the tax code. The tax code is amended to include reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments, with specific changes made to subparagraphs and sections in the code. The tax code is amended to include reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments by inserting new items in specific sections and subparagraphs. The tax code is amended to include reporting of excess home mortgage principal payments under Sec. 36C, effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
